thread.title: Woodridge man gets 6 years for trying to kidnap two teenage girls in 2013
thread.title_full: Woodridge man gets 6 years for trying to kidnap two teenage girls in 2013 | Chicago Sun-Times

author: | emailAddress.indexOf('@') == -1) {errorString = 'Please enter your email address';} var isError = false; if (errorString.length > 0) isError = true; if (isError) alert(errorString); return !isError;}
title: Woodridge man gets 6 years for trying to kidnap two teenage girls in 2013
text:
A 22-year-old man who attacked two girls in southwest suburban Bolingbrook on separate days in 2013 was sentenced to six years in prison Wednesday.
Kareem Green of Woodridge was found guilty on Aug. 14 of felony counts of attempted kidnapping, aggravated battery and unlawful restraint; and misdemeanor battery, according to the Will County state’s attorney office. He was sentenced Wednesday.
On Jan. 29, 2013, Green grabbed a 17-year-old girl from behind and attempted to carry her away as she walked home from Bolingbrook High School. A passing motorist stopped to help the girl and “frightened off the attacker,” who fled in a dark Ford Explorer, according to a statement from prosecutors.
Two days later, Green followed a 16-year-old girl as she walked to her girlfriend’s Bolingbrook apartment building after school. He grabbed the girl in the hallway and attempted to cover her mouth, but she struck him with her elbow and screamed for help, prosecutors said. Green then ran away.
Bolingbrook police searched vehicle records to identify people who owned dark Explorers and who fit the description provided by the two victims and the driver who helped the first girl. Detectives identified Green as a potential suspect, and he was later picked out of a photo lineup by all three witnesses, according to prosecutors.
“A dangerous man has been taken off our streets because of two brave girls who refused to become victims, a courageous good Samaritan who refused to look the other way, and dogged police work by detectives who refused to let their community become the hunting grounds for a predator,” State’s Attorney James Glasgow said in the statement.
Once he is released from prison, Green must register as a violent offender for 10 years, according to prosecutors.
